lines.text: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, IRAS, and ALEXAS

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Give me some music; music, moody food Of us that trade in love.

lines.speaker: attendants
lines.text: The music, ho!
Enter MARDIAN

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Let it alone; let's to billiards: come, Charmian.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: My arm is sore; best play with Mardian.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: As well a woman with an eunuch play'd As with a woman. Come, you'll play with me, sir?

lines.speaker: mardian
lines.text: As well as I can, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: And when good will is show'd, though't come too short, The actor may plead pardon. I'll none now: Give me mine angle; we'll to the river: there, My music playing far off, I will betray Tawny-finn'd fishes; my bended hook shall pierce Their slimy jaws; and, as I draw them up, I'll think them every one an Antony, And say 'Ah, ha! you're caught.'

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: 'Twas merry when You wager'd on your angling; when your diver Did hang a salt-fish on his hook, which he With fervency drew up.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: That time,--O times!-- I laugh'd him out of patience; and that night I laugh'd him into patience; and next morn, Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed; Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst I wore his sword Philippan. O, from Italy Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, madam,--

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Antonius dead!--If thou say so, villain, Thou kill'st thy mistress: but well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss; a hand that kings Have lipp'd, and trembled kissing.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: First, madam, he is well.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Why, there's more gold. But, sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well: bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Good madam, hear me.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Well, go to, I will; But there's no goodness in thy face: if Antony Be free and healthful,--so tart a favour To trumpet such good tidings! If not well, Thou shouldst come like a Fury crown'd with snakes, Not like a formal man.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Will't please you hear me?

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st: Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, I'll set thee in a shower of gold, and hail Rich pearls upon thee.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, he's well.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Well said.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: And friends with Caesar.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Thou'rt an honest man.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Make thee a fortune from me.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: But yet, madam,--

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I do not like 'But yet,' it does allay The good precedence; fie upon 'But yet'! 'But yet' is as a gaoler to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together: he's friends with Caesar: In state of health thou say'st; and thou say'st free.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Free, madam! no; I made no such report: He's bound unto Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: For what good turn?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: For the best turn i' the bed.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I am pale, Charmian.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Madam, he's married to Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!
Strikes him down

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Good madam, patience.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: What say you? Hence, Horrible villain! or I'll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me; I'll unhair thy head: Thou shalt be whipp'd with wire, and stew'd in brine, Smarting in lingering pickle.
Strikes him again
She hales him up and down

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Gracious madam, I that do bring the news made not the match.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Say 'tis not so, a province I will give thee, And make thy fortunes proud: the blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage; And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He's married, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.
Draws a knife

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Nay, then I'll run. What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.
Exit

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself: The man is innocent.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt. Melt Egypt into Nile! and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again: Though I am mad, I will not bite him: call.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: He is afeard to come.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I will not hurt him. These hands do lack nobility, that they strike A meaner than myself; since I myself Have given myself the cause. Come hither, sir. Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news: give to a gracious message. An host of tongues; but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.
Exit CHARMIAN
Re-enter CHARMIAN and Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I have done my duty.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: Is he married? I cannot hate thee worser than I do, If thou again say 'Yes.'

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He's married, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: The gods confound thee! dost thou hold there still?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Should I lie, madam?

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O, I would thou didst, So half my Egypt were submerged and made A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence: Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I crave your highness' pardon.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: He is married?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Take no offence that I would not offend you: To punish me for what you make me do. Seems much unequal: he's married to Octavia.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: O, that his fault should make a knave of thee, That art not what thou'rt sure of! Get thee hence: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me: lie they upon thy hand, And be undone by 'em!
Exit Messenger

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Good your highness, patience.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: In praising Antony, I have dispraised Caesar.

lines.speaker: charmian
lines.text: Many times, madam.

lines.speaker: cleopatra
lines.text: I am paid for't now. Lead me from hence: I faint: O Iras, Charmian! 'tis no matter. Go to the fellow, good Alexas; bid him Report the feature of Octavia, her years, Her inclination, let him not leave out The colour of her hair: bring me word quickly. Let him for ever go:--let him not--Charmian, Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon, The other way's a Mars. Bid you Alexas Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian, But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.
Exit ALEXAS
To MARDIAN
Exeunt
